10870Journal of Chemical CrystallographyJ Chem Crystallogr1074-15421572-8854Springer USBostons10870-013-0417-y41710.1007/s10870-013-0417-yBrief CommunicationSynthesis, Structure and Thermal Properties of Two New Nickel(II) Coordination Polymers Based on Diphenic Acid and Bis(Imidazole) LigandsLiuGuang-Xiang1aZhouHong1WangXiao-Feng1grid.440845.9School of Biochemical and Environmental EngineeringNanjing Xiaozhuang University211171NanjingPeople’s Republic of Chinanjuliugx@gmail.com152013620134363353416420132572012642013152013© Springer Science+Business Media New York 20132013Abstract

Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2·H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene), have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 35.504(4) Å, b = 7.6014(9) Å, c = 19.894(2) Å, β = 121.607(2)°, V = 4,572.6(9) Å3, Z = 8, R1 = 0.0461 and wR2 = 0.1193. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 21.623(2) Å, b = 13.9245(15) Å, c = 19.743(3) Å, β = 119.2360(10)°, V = 5,187.2(12) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0399 and wR2 = 0.1034. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). A careful structural comparison reveals the similarity of the Ni(II) coordination geometry and ligand binding mode. The significant discrepancy of their network structures may be attributed to the fluorinated substituent group.

Graphical Abstract

Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with (65.8) topology. The results show that the substituent group plays a significant role in the assembly process.

Great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of the construction of novel functional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) owing to their variety of intriguing architectures and topologies and their potential applications in magnetism, electric conductivity, molecular adsorption, heterogeneous catalysis, nonlinear optics and fluorescent materials [1–6]. The selection of the special ligand is very important in the construction of these coordination polymers. As an important family of multidentate O-donor ligands, organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been extensively employed in the preparation of such metal–organic complexes with multidimensional networks and interesting properties. Hence, the reported coordination polymers are mostly constructed by rigid polycarboxylate ligands [7–10]. Recently, more and more attention has been paid to the flexible polycarboxylate ligands, but studies about flexible polycarboxylate ligands are relatively few [11–13]. In the isomeric diphenic acid (H2DPA), the relative positions of the carboxylic acid groups are directly dependent on the angle between the two phenyl rings which should give rise to a more flexible coordination chemistry of this ligand.

On the other hand, the employment of mixed ligands during the self-assembly process has gradually become an effective approach, which is expected to obtain frameworks with more diverse structural motifs compared to using only one type of ligands. Flexible bis(imidazole) ligands bearing alkyl spacers, for example, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl-methyl)benzene (BIX) and 1,3-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (MBIX), have received the intense interest of chemists, because they can freely rotate to meet the requirement of coordination geometries of metal ions, and then produce unique structural motifs with beautiful aesthetics and useful functional properties [14–17]. However, fluorinated analogues of bis(imidazole) ligands have been seldom investigated [18–20]. In this regard, Shreeve and co-workers have reported a series of coordination polymers with bis(imidazole) or bis(methylimidazole) ligands bearing a fluorinated phenylene spacer [20]. To further understand the role of such fluorinated building blocks, we isolated two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers based on diphenic acid and 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene or 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene. In the paper, we report the synthesis, structural characterization, thermal properties of two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2·H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl) benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene).

ExperimentalMaterials and Measurements

All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. The ligands BIX and FBIX were prepared according to reported procedures [21]. C, H and N analyses were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in the range 4,000–400 cm−1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer by using KBr discs. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch STA-409PC instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1.

Synthesis of Complex 1

A mixture containing Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (116.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), H2DPA (48.4 mg, 0.2 mmol), BIX (47.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) and LiOH·H2O (16.8 mg, 0.4 mmol) in 15 ml deionized water was sealed in a 25 ml Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 140 °C for 3d. Green lamellar crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed with water and ethanol several times with a yield of 54 %. Anal. Calcd. for C28H22N4O4Ni: C, 62.60; H, 4.13; N, 10.43. Found: C, 62.55; H, 4.16; N, 10.42 %. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,378 (m), 3,057 (w), 2,921 (w), 1,581 (s), 1,565 (s), 1,531(s), 1,519 (m), 1,451 (w), 1,422 (m), 1,383 (s), 1,367 (s), 1,289 (w), 1,251 (m), 1,144 (w), 1,100 (m), 1,092 (m), 1,041 (m), 955 (w), 853 (w), 809 (w), 765 (w), 722 (w), 681 (w), 647 (w), 623 (w), 544 (w).

Synthesis of Complex 2

2 was obtained by the same method used for 1 except that FBIX (62.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was used instead of BIX as starting material. Green block crystals of 2 were obtained in 61 % yield. Anal. Calcd. for C56H38F8N8O9Ni2: C, 54.40; H, 3.10; N, 9.06. Found: C, 54.45; H, 3.13; N, 9.08 %. IR (KBr pellet, cm−1): 3,391 (m), 3,057 (w), 2,919 (w), 1,610 (s), 1,583 (s), 1,522 (m), 1,472 (m), 1,441 (w), 1,386 (m), 1,361 (s), 1,314 (m), 1,234 (m), 1,167 (m), 1,089 (m), 1,057 (w), 951 (m), 834 (w), 766 (m), 724 (m), 653 (w).

X-ray Crystallography

The crystallographic data collections for complexes 1 and 2 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The data were integrated by using the SAINT program [22], which also did the intensities corrected for Lorentz and polarization effect. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program [23]. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97 and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package [24, 25]. The hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. All calculations were performed on a personal computer with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package [25]. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement for two complexes are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bong angles are listed in Table 2.

Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited to the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, Nos. CCDC-802425 (1), CCDC- 802426 (2). This data can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; Fax: +44-1223-336033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam. ac.uk.

Results and DiscussionDescription of the Crystal Structures

Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c. The X-ray diffraction analysis shows complex 1 has a two-dimensional wave-like layer structure. In an asymmetric unit of 1, there are one unique Ni ion, two crystallographically independent BIX ligands and one DPA anion. Each Ni(II) ion is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct imidazole of two BIX ligands and four oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups of two DPA anions. Thus, Ni(II) center lies in a distorted octahedral environment as shown in Fig. 1. The Ni–O and Ni–N bonds distances are in the range of 2.0288(19)–2.3077(19) and 2.039(2)–2.048(2) Å, respectively. The bond angles range from 60.18(7)° to 162.82(8)°.

One of the BIX ligands lies on the inversion center with trans-configuration, the benzene ring of the other BIX ligand is perpendicular to the two-fold axis with cis-configuration. The DPA anion acts in a bis-chelating fashion and bridges two Ni(II) ions to generate one-dimensional chains along the b-axis with the Ni···Ni distance of 7.601(1) Å, which are further alternately linked by two different configurations of BIX ligands to yield a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer structure with (4,4) topology [26], as illustrated in Figs. 2 and 3. The Ni···Ni distances separated by the trans- and cis-configuration of bix ligand within the layer are 12.087(3) and 15.316(4) Å, respectively. In the crystal, adjacent 2D layers are stacked in a parallel manner, leading to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Fig. 4). Based on C···O distance calculations there are weak hydrogen bonding interactions, which might contribute to stabilization of the whole MOF structure.

In order to investigate the influence of the organic ligand on the structure of the complexes, reaction of H2DPA with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O in the present of FBIX were carried out, and 2 was obtained. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the structure of 2 contains one unique Ni(II) ion, one unique DPA dianion, two crystallographically independent FBIX ligands and half of one lattice water molecule. Each distorted octahedral Ni(II) center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms, coming from two DPA anions and two FBIX ligands (Ni–O = 2.0371(19)–2.258(2) Å, Ni–N = 2.029(2)–2.030(2) Å). The Ni–O and Ni–N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges [27]. Compared with complex 1, the most obvious difference is that both of the FBIX ligands lie on the inversion center with trans-configuration. Each DPA dianion in 2 coordinates to two Ni(II) ions with bis-chelating coordination mode. The adjacent Ni(II) ions are bridged by the DPA ligands to result in 1D Ni(II)-DPA helical chains along the b axis with the Ni···Ni distance of 7.3328(8) Å (Fig. 6). FBIX ligands link the right-handed and left-handed helical chains alternatively to construct 3D layer structure, So there is not chiral information in 1. From a topological perspective, if the Ni(II) ion is considered as a single node, this structure can be regarded as a uninodal four-connected net with (65.8) topology [28] (Fig. 7). The participation of the flexible FBIX ligand leads to the formation of a complicated 3D framework having small channels to host the guest water (4.9 % of the cell volume calculated by PLATON [29]). There exist strong O–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions among the oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 W···O2 = 2.802 Å). The hydrogen bonding interactions could enhance the stability of the complex.

FT-IR spectroscopy

The absence of such bands at around 1,700 cm−1 in the IR spectra of two complexes indicate the complete deprotonation of H2DPA ligand. Strong absorption peaks of 1,580 cm−1 and 1,380 cm−1 show the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups. The respective values of (υasym(COO−)–υsym(COO−)) suggest that the carboxylate group adopts bis-chelating coordination mode [30]. Also observed were the bands at ca. 1,520 cm−1, showing the C = N stretching vibration of imidazole group. All this agrees well with the result of X-ray single-crystal analyses.

Thermal property

To characterize the thermal stabilities of the two complexes, we carried out TGA analyses (Fig. 8). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 and 2 in a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The weight of complex 1 remains stable to approx. 320 °C, finally leading to the formation of stoichiometric amount of NiO as the residue. The TGA curve of 2 shows that the first weight loss of 1.50 % between 70 and 125 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule per formula unit, afterwards it is stable up to 265 °C. The framework collapsed in the temperature range 270–600 °C before the final formation of a metal oxide. Both complexes have good thermal stability, but their stability is lower than that of similar complexes [31], which may be attributed to the flexibility of auxiliary ligands.

Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized two novel coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). The results clearly indicate that the configuration of the bis(imidazole) ligand has important influence on the structure of the final products. Obviously, the two bis(imidazole) ligands involved in the construction of two complexes have the same imidazole group and a similar bis(monodentate) bridging coordination mode. The configuration of the two ligands is different, because the substituent group of the bis(imidazole) ligands cause different electronic effects and steric hindrance that change different configuration of the two ligands when coordinating to the Ni(II) ions and finally result in two distinct frameworks. This gives useful information for further understanding the possible factors that direct the formation of frameworks. Complexes with other metal ions are under investigation to study the generality of the fluorinated substituent effect.

IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3,378 (m), 3,057 (w), 2,921 (w), 1,581 (s), 1,565 (s), 1,531(s), 1,519 (m), 1,451 (w), 1,422 (m), 1,383 (s), 1,367 (s), 1,289 (w), 1,251 (m), 1,144 (w), 1,100 (m), 1,092 (m), 1,041 (m), 955 (w), 853 (w), 809 (w), 765 (w), 722 (w), 681 (w), 647 (w), 623 (w), 544 (w).Synthesis of Complex 22 was obtained by the same method used for 1 except that FBIX (62.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) was used instead of BIX as starting material. Green block crystals of 2 were obtained in 61 % yield. Anal. Calcd. for C56H38F8N8O9Ni2: C, 54.40; H, 3.10; N, 9.06. Found: C, 54.45; H, 3.13; N, 9.08 %. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3,391 (m), 3,057 (w), 2,919 (w), 1,610 (s), 1,583 (s), 1,522 (m), 1,472 (m), 1,441 (w), 1,386 (m), 1,361 (s), 1,314 (m), 1,234 (m), 1,167 (m), 1,089 (m), 1,057 (w), 951 (m), 834 (w), 766 (m), 724 (m), 653 (w).X-ray CrystallographyThe crystallographic data collections for complexes 1 and 2 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The data were integrated by using the SAINT program [22], which also did the intensities corrected for Lorentz and polarization effect. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program [23]. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97 and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package [24, 25]. The hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. All calculations were performed on a personal computer with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package [25]. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement for two complexes are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bong angles are listed in Table 2. Crystallographic data for the structural analysis have been deposited to the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, Nos. CCDC-802425 (1), CCDC- 802426 (2). This data can be obtained from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; Fax: +44-1223-336033; E-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam. ac.uk.Results and DiscussionDescription of the Crystal StructuresComplex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c. The X-ray diffraction analysis shows complex 1 has a two-dimensional wave-like layer structure. In an asymmetric unit of 1, there are one unique Ni ion, two crystallographically independent BIX ligands and one DPA anion. Each Ni(II) ion is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct imidazole of two BIX ligands and four oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups of two DPA anions. Thus, Ni(II) center lies in a distorted octahedral environment as shown in Fig. 1. The Ni-O and Ni-N bonds distances are in the range of 2.0288(19)-2.3077(19) and 2.039(2)-2.048(2) Å, respectively. The bond angles range from 60.18(7)° to 162.82(8)°. One of the BIX ligands lies on the inversion center with trans-configuration, the benzene ring of the other BIX ligand is perpendicular to the two-fold axis with cis-configuration. The DPA anion acts in a bis-chelating fashion and bridges two Ni(II) ions to generate one-dimensional chains along the b-axis with the Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance of 7.601(1) Å, which are further alternately linked by two different configurations of BIX ligands to yield a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer structure with (4,4) topology [26], as illustrated in Figs. 2 and 3. The Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distances separated by the trans- and cis-configuration of bix ligand within the layer are 12.087(3) and 15.316(4) Å, respectively. In the crystal, adjacent 2D layers are stacked in a parallel manner, leading to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Fig. 4). Based on C⋅⋅⋅O distance calculations there are weak hydrogen bonding interactions, which might contribute to stabilization of the whole MOF structure. In order to investigate the influence of the organic ligand on the structure of the complexes, reaction of H2DPA with Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O in the present of FBIX were carried out, and 2 was obtained. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the structure of 2 contains one unique Ni(II) ion, one unique DPA dianion, two crystallographically independent FBIX ligands and half of one lattice water molecule. Each distorted octahedral Ni(II) center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms, coming from two DPA anions and two FBIX ligands (Ni-O = 2.0371(19)-2.258(2) Å, Ni-N = 2.029(2)-2.030(2) Å). The Ni-O and Ni-N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges [27]. Compared with complex 1, the most obvious difference is that both of the FBIX ligands lie on the inversion center with trans-configuration. Each DPA dianion in 2 coordinates to two Ni(II) ions with bis-chelating coordination mode. The adjacent Ni(II) ions are bridged by the DPA ligands to result in 1D Ni(II)-DPA helical chains along the b axis with the Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance of 7.3328(8) Å (Fig. 6). FBIX ligands link the right-handed and left-handed helical chains alternatively to construct 3D layer structure, So there is not chiral information in 1. From a topological perspective, if the Ni(II) ion is considered as a single node, this structure can be regarded as a uninodal four-connected net with (65.8) topology [28] (Fig. 7). The participation of the flexible FBIX ligand leads to the formation of a complicated 3D framework having small channels to host the guest water (4.9 % of the cell volume calculated by PLATON [29]). There exist strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions among the oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 W⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.802 Å). The hydrogen bonding interactions could enhance the stability of the complex. FT-IR spectroscopyThe absence of such bands at around 1,700 cm-1 in the IR spectra of two complexes indicate the complete deprotonation of H2DPA ligand. Strong absorption peaks of 1,580 cm-1 and 1,380 cm-1 show the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups. The respective values of (υasym(COO-)-υsym(COO-)) suggest that the carboxylate group adopts bis-chelating coordination mode [30]. Also observed were the bands at ca. 1,520 cm-1, showing the C = N stretching vibration of imidazole group. All this agrees well with the result of X-ray single-crystal analyses.Thermal propertyTo characterize the thermal stabilities of the two complexes, we carried out TGA analyses (Fig. 8). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 and 2 in a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The weight of complex 1 remains stable to approx. 320 °C, finally leading to the formation of stoichiometric amount of NiO as the residue. The TGA curve of 2 shows that the first weight loss of 1.50 % between 70 and 125 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule per formula unit, afterwards it is stable up to 265 °C. The framework collapsed in the temperature range 270-600 °C before the final formation of a metal oxide. Both complexes have good thermal stability, but their stability is lower than that of similar complexes [31], which may be attributed to the flexibility of auxiliary ligands. ConclusionsWe have successfully synthesized two novel coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). The results clearly indicate that the configuration of the bis(imidazole) ligand has important influence on the structure of the final products. Obviously, the two bis(imidazole) ligands involved in the construction of two complexes have the same imidazole group and a similar bis(monodentate) bridging coordination mode. The configuration of the two ligands is different, because the substituent group of the bis(imidazole) ligands cause different electronic effects and steric hindrance that change different configuration of the two ligands when coordinating to the Ni(II) ions and finally result in two distinct frameworks. This gives useful information for further understanding the possible factors that direct the formation of frameworks. Complexes with other metal ions are under investigation to study the generality of the fluorinated substituent effect.AcknowledgmentsWe are grateful to the National Natural Science Foundation of China elements.content: Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2·H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene), have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 35.504(4) Å, b = 7.6014(9) Å, c = 19.894(2) Å, β = 121.607(2)°, V = 4,572.6(9) Å3, Z = 8, R1 = 0.0461 and wR2 = 0.1193. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 21.623(2) Å, b = 13.9245(15) Å, c = 19.743(3) Å, β = 119.2360(10)°, V = 5,187.2(12) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0399 and wR2 = 0.1034. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). A careful structural comparison reveals the similarity of the Ni(II) coordination geometry and ligand binding mode. The significant discrepancy of their network structures may be attributed to the fluorinated substituent group.

Abstract

Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2⋅H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene), have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 35.504(4) Å, b = 7.6014(9) Å, c = 19.894(2) Å, β = 121.607(2)°, V = 4,572.6(9) Å3, Z = 8, R1 = 0.0461 and wR2 = 0.1193. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 21.623(2) Å, b = 13.9245(15) Å, c = 19.743(3) Å, β = 119.2360(10)°, V = 5,187.2(12) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0399 and wR2 = 0.1034. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). A careful structural comparison reveals the similarity of the Ni(II) coordination geometry and ligand binding mode. The significant discrepancy of their network structures may be attributed to the fluorinated substituent group.

Graphical Abstract

Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with (65.8) topology. The results show that the substituent group plays a significant role in the assembly process.

elements.content: Great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of the construction of novel functional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) owing to their variety of intriguing architectures and topologies and their potential applications in magnetism, electric conductivity, molecular adsorption, heterogeneous catalysis, nonlinear optics and fluorescent materials [1–6]. The selection of the special ligand is very important in the construction of these coordination polymers. As an important family of multidentate O-donor ligands, organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been extensively employed in the preparation of such metal–organic complexes with multidimensional networks and interesting properties. Hence, the reported coordination polymers are mostly constructed by rigid polycarboxylate ligands [7–10]. Recently, more and more attention has been paid to the flexible polycarboxylate ligands, but studies about flexible polycarboxylate ligands are relatively few [11–13]. In the isomeric diphenic acid (H2DPA), the relative positions of the carboxylic acid groups are directly dependent on the angle between the two phenyl rings which should give rise to a more flexible coordination chemistry of this ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Great interest has been focused on the rapidly expanding field of the construction of novel functional metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) owing to their variety of intriguing architectures and topologies and their potential applications in magnetism, electric conductivity, molecular adsorption, heterogeneous catalysis, nonlinear optics and fluorescent materials [1-6]. The selection of the special ligand is very important in the construction of these coordination polymers. As an important family of multidentate O-donor ligands, organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands have been extensively employed in the preparation of such metal-organic complexes with multidimensional networks and interesting properties. Hence, the reported coordination polymers are mostly constructed by rigid polycarboxylate ligands [7-10]. Recently, more and more attention has been paid to the flexible polycarboxylate ligands, but studies about flexible polycarboxylate ligands are relatively few [11-13]. In the isomeric diphenic acid (H2DPA), the relative positions of the carboxylic acid groups are directly dependent on the angle between the two phenyl rings which should give rise to a more flexible coordination chemistry of this ligand.

elements.content: On the other hand, the employment of mixed ligands during the self-assembly process has gradually become an effective approach, which is expected to obtain frameworks with more diverse structural motifs compared to using only one type of ligands. Flexible bis(imidazole) ligands bearing alkyl spacers, for example, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl-methyl)benzene (BIX) and 1,3-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene (MBIX), have received the intense interest of chemists, because they can freely rotate to meet the requirement of coordination geometries of metal ions, and then produce unique structural motifs with beautiful aesthetics and useful functional properties [14–17]. However, fluorinated analogues of bis(imidazole) ligands have been seldom investigated [18–20]. In this regard, Shreeve and co-workers have reported a series of coordination polymers with bis(imidazole) or bis(methylimidazole) ligands bearing a fluorinated phenylene spacer [20]. To further understand the role of such fluorinated building blocks, we isolated two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers based on diphenic acid and 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene or 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene. In the paper, we report the synthesis, structural characterization, thermal properties of two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2·H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl) benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene).

Experimental

Materials and Measurements

All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. The ligands BIX and FBIX were prepared according to reported procedures [21]. C, H and N analyses were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded in the range 4,000-400 cm-1 on a Bruker Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer by using KBr discs. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a Netzsch STA-409PC instrument in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1.

The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement for two complexes are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bong angles are listed in Table 2.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

The crystallographic data collections for complexes 1 and 2 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The data were integrated by using the SAINT program [22], which also did the intensities corrected for Lorentz and polarization effect. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program [23]. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97 and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package [24, 25]. The hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically. All calculations were performed on a personal computer with the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package [25]. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection and refinement for two complexes are summarized in Table 1. Selected bond lengths and bong angles are listed in Table 2.

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c. The X-ray diffraction analysis shows complex 1 has a two-dimensional wave-like layer structure. In an asymmetric unit of 1, there are one unique Ni ion, two crystallographically independent BIX ligands and one DPA anion. Each Ni(II) ion is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct imidazole of two BIX ligands and four oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups of two DPA anions. Thus, Ni(II) center lies in a distorted octahedral environment as shown in Fig. 1. The Ni–O and Ni–N bonds distances are in the range of 2.0288(19)–2.3077(19) and 2.039(2)–2.048(2) Å, respectively. The bond angles range from 60.18(7)° to 162.82(8)°.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of the Crystal Structures

Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c. The X-ray diffraction analysis shows complex 1 has a two-dimensional wave-like layer structure. In an asymmetric unit of 1, there are one unique Ni ion, two crystallographically independent BIX ligands and one DPA anion. Each Ni(II) ion is six-coordinated by two nitrogen atoms from two distinct imidazole of two BIX ligands and four oxygen atoms from two different carboxylate groups of two DPA anions. Thus, Ni(II) center lies in a distorted octahedral environment as shown in Fig. 1. The Ni-O and Ni-N bonds distances are in the range of 2.0288(19)-2.3077(19) and 2.039(2)-2.048(2) Å, respectively. The bond angles range from 60.18(7)° to 162.82(8)°.

elements.content: The coordination environment of Ni(II) atom in 1 with 30 % thermal ellipsoids, all hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1The coordination environment of Ni(II) atom in 1 with 30 % thermal ellipsoids, all hydrogen atoms are omitted for clarity

elements.content: One of the BIX ligands lies on the inversion center with trans-configuration, the benzene ring of the other BIX ligand is perpendicular to the two-fold axis with cis-configuration. The DPA anion acts in a bis-chelating fashion and bridges two Ni(II) ions to generate one-dimensional chains along the b-axis with the Ni···Ni distance of 7.601(1) Å, which are further alternately linked by two different configurations of BIX ligands to yield a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer structure with (4,4) topology [26], as illustrated in Figs. 2 and 3. The Ni···Ni distances separated by the trans- and cis-configuration of bix ligand within the layer are 12.087(3) and 15.316(4) Å, respectively. In the crystal, adjacent 2D layers are stacked in a parallel manner, leading to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Fig. 4). Based on C···O distance calculations there are weak hydrogen bonding interactions, which might contribute to stabilization of the whole MOF structure.
elements.clean_text: One of the BIX ligands lies on the inversion center with trans-configuration, the benzene ring of the other BIX ligand is perpendicular to the two-fold axis with cis-configuration. The DPA anion acts in a bis-chelating fashion and bridges two Ni(II) ions to generate one-dimensional chains along the b-axis with the Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance of 7.601(1) Å, which are further alternately linked by two different configurations of BIX ligands to yield a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer structure with (4,4) topology [26], as illustrated in Figs. 2 and 3. The Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distances separated by the trans- and cis-configuration of bix ligand within the layer are 12.087(3) and 15.316(4) Å, respectively. In the crystal, adjacent 2D layers are stacked in a parallel manner, leading to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure (Fig. 4). Based on C⋅⋅⋅O distance calculations there are weak hydrogen bonding interactions, which might contribute to stabilization of the whole MOF structure.

elements.content: In order to investigate the influence of the organic ligand on the structure of the complexes, reaction of H2DPA with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O in the present of FBIX were carried out, and 2 was obtained. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic symmetry space group C2/c. As illustrated in Fig. 5, the structure of 2 contains one unique Ni(II) ion, one unique DPA dianion, two crystallographically independent FBIX ligands and half of one lattice water molecule. Each distorted octahedral Ni(II) center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms, coming from two DPA anions and two FBIX ligands (Ni–O = 2.0371(19)–2.258(2) Å, Ni–N = 2.029(2)–2.030(2) Å). The Ni–O and Ni–N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges [27]. Compared with complex 1, the most obvious difference is that both of the FBIX ligands lie on the inversion center with trans-configuration. Each DPA dianion in 2 coordinates to two Ni(II) ions with bis-chelating coordination mode. The adjacent Ni(II) ions are bridged by the DPA ligands to result in 1D Ni(II)-DPA helical chains along the b axis with the Ni···Ni distance of 7.3328(8) Å (Fig. 6). FBIX ligands link the right-handed and left-handed helical chains alternatively to construct 3D layer structure, So there is not chiral information in 1. From a topological perspective, if the Ni(II) ion is considered as a single node, this structure can be regarded as a uninodal four-connected net with (65.8) topology [28] (Fig. 7). The participation of the flexible FBIX ligand leads to the formation of a complicated 3D framework having small channels to host the guest water (4.9 % of the cell volume calculated by PLATON [29]). There exist strong O–H···O hydrogen bonding interactions among the oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 W···O2 = 2.802 Å). The hydrogen bonding interactions could enhance the stability of the complex.

As illustrated in Fig. 5, the structure of 2 contains one unique Ni(II) ion, one unique DPA dianion, two crystallographically independent FBIX ligands and half of one lattice water molecule. Each distorted octahedral Ni(II) center is coordinated by four oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms, coming from two DPA anions and two FBIX ligands (Ni-O = 2.0371(19)-2.258(2) Å, Ni-N = 2.029(2)-2.030(2) Å). The Ni-O and Ni-N bond lengths are all within the normal ranges [27]. Compared with complex 1, the most obvious difference is that both of the FBIX ligands lie on the inversion center with trans-configuration. Each DPA dianion in 2 coordinates to two Ni(II) ions with bis-chelating coordination mode. The adjacent Ni(II) ions are bridged by the DPA ligands to result in 1D Ni(II)-DPA helical chains along the b axis with the Ni⋅⋅⋅Ni distance of 7.3328(8) Å (Fig. 6). FBIX ligands link the right-handed and left-handed helical chains alternatively to construct 3D layer structure, So there is not chiral information in 1. From a topological perspective, if the Ni(II) ion is considered as a single node, this structure can be regarded as a uninodal four-connected net with (65.8) topology [28] (Fig. 7). The participation of the flexible FBIX ligand leads to the formation of a complicated 3D framework having small channels to host the guest water (4.9 % of the cell volume calculated by PLATON [29]). There exist strong O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonding interactions among the oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules and the carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1 W⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.802 Å). The hydrogen bonding interactions could enhance the stability of the complex.

elements.content: The absence of such bands at around 1,700 cm−1 in the IR spectra of two complexes indicate the complete deprotonation of H2DPA ligand. Strong absorption peaks of 1,580 cm−1 and 1,380 cm−1 show the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups. The respective values of (υasym(COO−)–υsym(COO−)) suggest that the carboxylate group adopts bis-chelating coordination mode [30]. Also observed were the bands at ca. 1,520 cm−1, showing the C = N stretching vibration of imidazole group. All this agrees well with the result of X-ray single-crystal analyses.
elements.clean_text:
FT-IR spectroscopy

The absence of such bands at around 1,700 cm-1 in the IR spectra of two complexes indicate the complete deprotonation of H2DPA ligand. Strong absorption peaks of 1,580 cm-1 and 1,380 cm-1 show the typical antisymmetric and symmetric stretching bands of carboxylate groups. The respective values of (υasym(COO-)-υsym(COO-)) suggest that the carboxylate group adopts bis-chelating coordination mode [30]. Also observed were the bands at ca. 1,520 cm-1, showing the C = N stretching vibration of imidazole group. All this agrees well with the result of X-ray single-crystal analyses.

elements.content: To characterize the thermal stabilities of the two complexes, we carried out TGA analyses (Fig. 8). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 and 2 in a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The weight of complex 1 remains stable to approx. 320 °C, finally leading to the formation of stoichiometric amount of NiO as the residue. The TGA curve of 2 shows that the first weight loss of 1.50 % between 70 and 125 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule per formula unit, afterwards it is stable up to 265 °C. The framework collapsed in the temperature range 270–600 °C before the final formation of a metal oxide. Both complexes have good thermal stability, but their stability is lower than that of similar complexes [31], which may be attributed to the flexibility of auxiliary ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Thermal property

To characterize the thermal stabilities of the two complexes, we carried out TGA analyses (Fig. 8). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 and 2 in a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The weight of complex 1 remains stable to approx. 320 °C, finally leading to the formation of stoichiometric amount of NiO as the residue. The TGA curve of 2 shows that the first weight loss of 1.50 % between 70 and 125 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule per formula unit, afterwards it is stable up to 265 °C. The framework collapsed in the temperature range 270-600 °C before the final formation of a metal oxide. Both complexes have good thermal stability, but their stability is lower than that of similar complexes [31], which may be attributed to the flexibility of auxiliary ligands.

elements.content: We have successfully synthesized two novel coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). The results clearly indicate that the configuration of the bis(imidazole) ligand has important influence on the structure of the final products. Obviously, the two bis(imidazole) ligands involved in the construction of two complexes have the same imidazole group and a similar bis(monodentate) bridging coordination mode. The configuration of the two ligands is different, because the substituent group of the bis(imidazole) ligands cause different electronic effects and steric hindrance that change different configuration of the two ligands when coordinating to the Ni(II) ions and finally result in two distinct frameworks. This gives useful information for further understanding the possible factors that direct the formation of frameworks. Complexes with other metal ions are under investigation to study the generality of the fluorinated substituent effect.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We have successfully synthesized two novel coordination polymers under hydrothermal conditions. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). The results clearly indicate that the configuration of the bis(imidazole) ligand has important influence on the structure of the final products. Obviously, the two bis(imidazole) ligands involved in the construction of two complexes have the same imidazole group and a similar bis(monodentate) bridging coordination mode. The configuration of the two ligands is different, because the substituent group of the bis(imidazole) ligands cause different electronic effects and steric hindrance that change different configuration of the two ligands when coordinating to the Ni(II) ions and finally result in two distinct frameworks. This gives useful information for further understanding the possible factors that direct the formation of frameworks. Complexes with other metal ions are under investigation to study the generality of the fluorinated substituent effect.

cln_elements.content:
Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2·H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene), have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 35.504(4) Å, b = 7.6014(9) Å, c = 19.894(2) Å, β = 121.607(2)°, V = 4,572.6(9) Å3, Z = 8, R1 = 0.0461 and wR2 = 0.1193. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 21.623(2) Å, b = 13.9245(15) Å, c = 19.743(3) Å, β = 119.2360(10)°, V = 5,187.2(12) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0399 and wR2 = 0.1034. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). A careful structural comparison reveals the similarity of the Ni(II) coordination geometry and ligand binding mode. The significant discrepancy of their network structures may be attributed to the fluorinated substituent group.

Thermal property

To characterize the thermal stabilities of the two complexes, we carried out TGA analyses (Fig. 8). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 and 2 in a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The weight of complex 1 remains stable to approx. 320 °C, finally leading to the formation of stoichiometric amount of NiO as the residue. The TGA curve of 2 shows that the first weight loss of 1.50 % between 70 and 125 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule per formula unit, afterwards it is stable up to 265 °C. The framework collapsed in the temperature range 270–600 °C before the final formation of a metal oxide. Both complexes have good thermal stability, but their stability is lower than that of similar complexes [31], which may be attributed to the flexibility of auxiliary ligands.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Two novel nickel(II) coordination polymers, Ni(DPA)(BIX) (1) and Ni2(DPA)2(FBIX)2⋅H2O (2) (H2DPA = diphenic acid, BIX = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene and FBIX = 2,3,5,6-tetrafluoro-1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene), have been synthesized under the hydrothermal conditions and characterized by IR, elemental analysis and single crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 35.504(4) Å, b = 7.6014(9) Å, c = 19.894(2) Å, β = 121.607(2)°, V = 4,572.6(9) Å3, Z = 8, R1 = 0.0461 and wR2 = 0.1193. Complex 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c with unit cell dimensions a = 21.623(2) Å, b = 13.9245(15) Å, c = 19.743(3) Å, β = 119.2360(10)°, V = 5,187.2(12) Å3, Z = 4, R1 = 0.0399 and wR2 = 0.1034. Complex 1 affords a two-dimensional (2D) wave-like layer network based on the intersection of Ni-BIX and Ni-DPA chains, while complex 2 is an interesting three-dimensional (3D) 4-connected network with a point symbol of (65.8). A careful structural comparison reveals the similarity of the Ni(II) coordination geometry and ligand binding mode. The significant discrepancy of their network structures may be attributed to the fluorinated substituent group.

Thermal property

To characterize the thermal stabilities of the two complexes, we carried out TGA analyses (Fig. 8). The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1 and 2 in a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The weight of complex 1 remains stable to approx. 320 °C, finally leading to the formation of stoichiometric amount of NiO as the residue. The TGA curve of 2 shows that the first weight loss of 1.50 % between 70 and 125 °C corresponds to the loss of one lattice water molecule per formula unit, afterwards it is stable up to 265 °C. The framework collapsed in the temperature range 270-600 °C before the final formation of a metal oxide. Both complexes have good thermal stability, but their stability is lower than that of similar complexes [31], which may be attributed to the flexibility of auxiliary ligands.
